clusters.neutral_headline: Worker Dies After Partial Collapse of Medieval Tower in Rome

items.title: Worker dies after partial collapse of medieval tower in Rome
items.standfirst: The man was trapped for several hours after part of the Torre dei Conti, on the edge of the Roman Forum, gave way.
items.content: The man was trapped for several hours after part of the Torre dei Conti, on the edge of the Roman Forum, gave way.

items.title: Worker dies in Italy after rescue from partially collapsed medieval tower
items.standfirst: The Romanian worker was trapped for hours under the rubble following the partial collapse of Rome's Torre dei Conti.
items.content: The Romanian worker was trapped for hours under the rubble following the partial collapse of Rome's Torre dei Conti.

items.title: Worker dies after Rome's medieval Torre dei Conti tower partially collapses
items.standfirst: The 13th century Torre dei Conti in Rome partially collapsed during renovation work. One worker who was extracted from the rubble died soon after, officials said.
items.content: The 13th century Torre dei Conti in Rome partially collapsed during renovation work. One worker who was extracted from the rubble died soon after, officials said.

items.title: Worker dies after being rescued from partially collapsed medieval tower in Rome
items.standfirst: Romanian worker was taken to hospital in ‘serious condition’ after being saved from Torre dei Conti rubble, but died soon afterA Romanian worker who was trapped for hours under rubble in Rome after the partial collapse of a medieval tower has died in hospital, just a short time after he was pulled free by emergency services.“I express deep sorrow and condolences, on behalf of myself and the government, for the tragic loss of Octay Stroici, the worker who was killed in the collapse of the Torre dei Conti in Rome,” Italy’s prime minister Giorgia Meloni said in a statement after midnight. “​We are close to his family and colleagues at this time of unspeakable suffering.” Continue reading...
items.content: Romanian worker was taken to hospital in ‘serious condition’ after being saved from Torre dei Conti rubble, but died soon afterA Romanian worker who was trapped for hours under rubble in Rome after the partial collapse of a medieval tower has died in hospital, just a short time after he was pulled free by emergency services.“I express deep sorrow and condolences, on behalf of myself and the government, for the tragic loss of Octay Stroici, the worker who was killed in the collapse of the Torre dei Conti in Rome,” Italy’s prime minister Giorgia Meloni said in a statement after midnight. “​We are close to his family and colleagues at this time of unspeakable suffering.” Continue reading...

items.title: Worker dies after medieval tower collapses during renovation in Rome
items.standfirst: Rescuers in Rome on Monday pulled alive a worker trapped when a medieval tower partly collapsed during renovation, city authorities said. The man was taken to hospital with injuries. Prefect Lamberto Giannini described the effort as a “long rescue mission.”
items.content: Rescuers in Rome on Monday pulled alive a worker trapped when a medieval tower partly collapsed during renovation, city authorities said. The man was taken to hospital with injuries. Prefect Lamberto Giannini described the effort as a “long rescue mission.”

items.title: Worker trapped after medieval Rome tower partially collapses
items.standfirst: Video shows part of Rome’s medieval Torre dei Conti collapse for a second time during restoration near the Colosseum
items.content: Video shows part of Rome’s medieval Torre dei Conti collapse for a second time during restoration near the Colosseum

items.title: Medieval tower partially collapses in central Rome
items.standfirst: The Torre dei Conti medieval tower in central #Rome was under renovation when it partially collapsed on November 3 just after 11:30 am local time. One worker is believed to be trapped alive under rubble, while three others were evacuated, with one taken to hospital in critical condition, a firefighter spokesman told AFP. The tower is in a busy area, just off the Imperial Forum and close to the #Colosseum, #Italy's top tourist site.
items.content: The Torre dei Conti medieval tower in central #Rome was under renovation when it partially collapsed on November 3 just after 11:30 am local time. One worker is believed to be trapped alive under rubble, while three others were evacuated, with one taken to hospital in critical condition, a firefighter spokesman told AFP. The tower is in a busy area, just off the Imperial Forum and close to the #Colosseum, #Italy's top tourist site.

items.title: Medieval tower partially collapses in the heart of Rome
items.standfirst: The Torre dei Conti partially collapsed in Rome during renovations, critically injuring one worker and trapping another.
items.content: The Torre dei Conti partially collapsed in Rome during renovations, critically injuring one worker and trapping another.

items.title: Worker trapped under collapsed medieval tower for 11 hours dies
items.standfirst: A man who was trapped under the rubble of a collapsed medieval tower in central Rome has died.
items.content: A man who was trapped under the rubble of a collapsed medieval tower in central Rome has died.

ai_summary: A worker died after being trapped in the Torre dei Conti collapse in Rome.
The tower partially collapsed during renovation work, trapping the worker.
Emergency services rescued the worker, but he died shortly after.
Italian Prime Minister expressed condolences for the worker's death.
The collapse occurred in the 13th-century Torre dei Conti near the Roman Forum.

items.title: Israel rocked by scandal as top military lawyer resigns, goes missing, is found and thrown into jail
Israel says arrested ex-military prosecutor after leaked abuse video
items.standfirst: Israeli police arrested former military prosecutor Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, the national security minister said Monday, following a scandal that erupted after she leaked a video appearing to show soldiers abusing a Palestinian detainee. Tomer-Yerushalmi disappeared for several hours on Sunday after she announced her resignation, with speculation swirling in the press of a possible suicide attempt. FRANCE 24's Jennie Shin reports.
items.content: Israeli police arrested former military prosecutor Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, the national security minister said Monday, following a scandal that erupted after she leaked a video appearing to show soldiers abusing a Palestinian detainee. Tomer-Yerushalmi disappeared for several hours on Sunday after she announced her resignation, with speculation swirling in the press of a possible suicide attempt. FRANCE 24's Jennie Shin reports.

items.standfirst: Israeli police arrested the military's former top lawyer, Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, who leaked a video showing the abuse of a Palestinian detainee. The video has triggered international outrage. France 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.

items.title: Israel top military lawyer arrested after she admitted leaking video of soldiers’ abuse
items.standfirst: Rightwing politicians and pundits have called the soldiers accused of attack on Palestinian detainee ‘heroes’ and military investigators traitors Police in Israel have arrested and detained the military’s top legal officer after she admitted leaking footage of soldiers allegedly attacking a Palestinian detainee and then in effect lying about her actions to Israel’s high court.The military advocate general, Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, said in a resignation letter last week that she had authorised publication of the video to defuse attacks on military investigators and prosecutors working on the case. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump threatens to cut funds if ‘communist’ Mamdani wins mayoral election
items.standfirst: President backs Cuomo in election eve Truth Social post as Mamdani hits back at Trump’s ‘threat – it is not the law’On the eve of New York’s well-watched mayoral election, President Donald Trump issued a threat to its voters: stop Zohran Mamdani or pay.“If Communist Candidate Zohran Mamdani wins the Election for Mayor of New York City, it is highly unlikely that I will be contributing Federal Funds, other than the very minimum as required, to my beloved first home,” Trump said in a post on Truth Social. “I don’t want to send, as President, good money after bad.” Continue reading...

items.title: White House to offer reduced food aid during shutdown after court order
items.standfirst: The government will offer partial food assistance to 42 million low-income Americans after federal courts last week ordered the Trump administration to use emergency funds for the payments during the shutdown, the White House said Monday. The emergency funds cover about half of the food aid budget for November.

items.title: ChatGPT owner OpenAI signs $38bn cloud computing deal with Amazon
items.standfirst: The seven-year agreement will see OpenAI gain access to Nvidia graphics processors to train its artificial intelligence models.
items.content: The seven-year agreement will see OpenAI gain access to Nvidia graphics processors to train its artificial intelligence models.

items.title: OpenAI signs massive AI compute deal with Amazon
items.standfirst: Deal will provide access to hundreds of thousands of Nvidia chips that power ChatGPT.
items.content: On Monday, OpenAI announced it has signed a seven-year, $38 billion deal to buy cloud services from Amazon Web Services to power products like ChatGPT and Sora. It’s the company’s first big computing deal after a fundamental restructuring last week that gave OpenAI more operational and financial freedom from Microsoft. The agreement gives OpenAI access to hundreds of thousands of Nvidia graphics processors to train and run its AI models. “Scaling frontier AI requires massive, reliable compute,” OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said in a statement. “Our partnership with AWS strengthens the broad compute ecosystem that will power this next era and bring advanced AI to everyone.” OpenAI will reportedly use Amazon Web Services immediately, with all planned capacity set to come online by the end of 2026 and room to expand further in 2027 and beyond. Amazon plans to roll out hundreds of thousands of chips, including Nvidia’s GB200 and GB300 AI accelerators, in data clusters built to power ChatGPT’s responses, generate AI videos, and train OpenAI’s next wave of models.Read full article Comments

items.content: Microsoft Corp. has signed a roughly $9.7 billion deal to buy artificial intelligence computing capacity from IREN Ltd., becoming the Australian company’s largest customer. Bloomberg's Caroline Hyde reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

clusters.title: Powerful Afghan earthquake leaves at least 20 dead and hundreds injured
clusters.neutral_headline: Earthquake in Afghanistan Kills at Least 20 People

items.title: Powerful Afghan earthquake leaves at least 20 dead and hundreds injured
items.standfirst: Northern provinces of Balkh and Samangan worst hit by magnitude 6.3 quake, which also damaged Mazar-i-Sharif’s Blue MosqueA powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake shook northern Afghanistan before dawn on Monday, killing at least 20 people and injuring more than 640 others, 25 critically, a disaster management official said. Health officials said the numbers could rise.The US Geological Survey said the quake’s epicentre was located 22km (14 miles) south-west of the town of Khulm, and that it struck at 12.59am at a depth of 28km (17 miles). Continue reading...

Health officials said the numbers could rise.The US Geological Survey said the quake’s epicentre was located 22km (14 miles) south-west of the town of Khulm, and that it struck at 12.59am at a depth of 28km (17 miles). clusters.title: Zohran Mamdani called out Donald Trump’s threat to withhold federal funding in New York City– as it happened
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump's Tariffs Face Supreme Court Scrutiny

items.title: Zohran Mamdani called out Donald Trump’s threat to withhold federal funding in New York City– as it happened
items.standfirst: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: president endorses and threatens on eve of New York City mayoral electionLooking ahead, on Wednesday, the supreme court will hear arguments on whether Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs on dozens of countries are legal. It’s set to be one of the most consequential rulings on the expanse of Trump’s presidential power in his second term.My colleague, Eduardo Porter, has this helpful breakdown on the question at the heart of this case. A dozen states have challenged the president’s contention that the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) of 1977 gives him the power to impose tariffs on imports from every country in the world to defend the nation from a several “threats” facing the US.Justices will focus much of their attention on whether IEEPA authorizes the president to levy a tariff – a word that is not mentioned in the text of the law and is, moreover, a form of taxation, over which, per the constitution, Congress has exclusive power.IEEPA gives the president authority “to deal with any unusual and extraordinary threat, which has its source in whole or substantial part outside the United States, to the national security, foreign policy, or economy of the United States, if the president declares a national emergency with respect to such threat”. Continue reading...
items.content: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: president endorses and threatens on eve of New York City mayoral electionLooking ahead, on Wednesday, the supreme court will hear arguments on whether Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs on dozens of countries are legal. It’s set to be one of the most consequential rulings on the expanse of Trump’s presidential power in his second term.My colleague, Eduardo Porter, has this helpful breakdown on the question at the heart of this case. A dozen states have challenged the president’s contention that the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) of 1977 gives him the power to impose tariffs on imports from every country in the world to defend the nation from a several “threats” facing the US.Justices will focus much of their attention on whether IEEPA authorizes the president to levy a tariff – a word that is not mentioned in the text of the law and is, moreover, a form of taxation, over which, per the constitution, Congress has exclusive power.IEEPA gives the president authority “to deal with any unusual and extraordinary threat, which has its source in whole or substantial part outside the United States, to the national security, foreign policy, or economy of the United States, if the president declares a national emergency with respect to such threat”. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump 'allocating himself a power that he does not have' on tariffs, expert says
items.standfirst: The U.S. Supreme Court holds oral arguments on Wednesday over the legality of President Donald Trump's tariffs imposed under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Frederick T. Davis, Former Federal Prosecutor and Lecturer in Law at Columbia University, says that Trump 'is allocating himself a power that he does not have' and that the Supreme Court 'should say so'.
items.content: The U.S. Supreme Court holds oral arguments on Wednesday over the legality of President Donald Trump's tariffs imposed under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Frederick T. Davis, Former Federal Prosecutor and Lecturer in Law at Columbia University, says that Trump 'is allocating himself a power that he does not have' and that the Supreme Court 'should say so'.

items.title: The president who cried tariffs: will the US supreme court challenge Trump’s trade war?
items.standfirst: The US high court will hear arguments on whether Trump’s erratic imposition of global tariffs is legally validDonald Trump thrives on emergencies. He cried havoc on the very first day of his second term, declaring a national emergency caused by an “invasion” of “illegal aliens” from Mexico. He has since invoked emergencies more than any president since the passage of the National Emergencies Act in 1976.Next Wednesday, he faces another of his own making, as the US supreme court hears oral arguments on whether his globe-shaking signature economic policy – tariffs – is legally valid. Continue reading...
items.content: The US high court will hear arguments on whether Trump’s erratic imposition of global tariffs is legally validDonald Trump thrives on emergencies. He cried havoc on the very first day of his second term, declaring a national emergency caused by an “invasion” of “illegal aliens” from Mexico. He has since invoked emergencies more than any president since the passage of the National Emergencies Act in 1976.Next Wednesday, he faces another of his own making, as the US supreme court hears oral arguments on whether his globe-shaking signature economic policy – tariffs – is legally valid. Continue reading...

The tariffs affect imports from numerous countries.

items.title: Shein bans sex dolls after France threatens to block market access
items.standfirst: Chinese e-commerce giant Shein has come under renewed pressure in France, just days before it opens its first permanent physical retail space in Paris. France's consumer watchdog said it had discovered child-like sex dolls on the e-commerce platform, prompting the government to warn it could block its market access. In response the Chinese-owned company suspended its 'adult products' category. Also in the segment, Huawei's massive factory being built in Alsace faces an uncertain future.
items.content: Chinese e-commerce giant Shein has come under renewed pressure in France, just days before it opens its first permanent physical retail space in Paris. France's consumer watchdog said it had discovered child-like sex dolls on the e-commerce platform, prompting the government to warn it could block its market access. In response the Chinese-owned company suspended its 'adult products' category. Also in the segment, Huawei's massive factory being built in Alsace faces an uncertain future.

The French finance minister has threatened to ban the retailer from the country if it resumed selling the dolls.
items.content: Asian e-commerce giant Shein said Monday it was banning sex dolls from sale online after France’s anti-fraud unit said “childlike” dolls of a likely pornographic nature were being sold on the company’s platform. items.content: Authorities identify the remains handed over on Sunday, bringing to eight the number of hostages' bodies still to be found in Gaza.

items.title: Hamas returns bodies of 3 deceased hostages to Israel
items.standfirst: Hamas returned the bodies of three hostages to Israel on Sunday, with the International Committee of the Red Cross once again serving as an intermediary, officials said
items.content: Hamas returned the bodies of three hostages to Israel on Sunday, with the International Committee of the Red Cross once again serving as an intermediary, officials said

ai_summary: Israel confirmed Hamas returned bodies of three soldiers held hostage.
The remains were identified by authorities on Sunday.
The International Committee of the Red Cross served as intermediary.
Eight hostages' bodies remain to be found in Gaza.
